The **Super Bowl ring** is an award in the [National Football
League](/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League") given to
the winners of the league's annual championship game, the [Super
Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl "Super Bowl"). Since only one [Vince Lombardi
Trophy](/wiki/Vince_Lombardi_Trophy "Vince Lombardi Trophy") is awarded to the
team (ownership) itself, the Super Bowl ring offers a collectable memento for
the actual players and team members to keep for themselves to symbolise their
victory.

## Details[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_ring&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Details")]

These rings are typically made of [yellow](/wiki/Gold "Gold") or [white
gold](/wiki/White_gold "White gold") with [diamonds](/wiki/Diamonds
"Diamonds"). They usually include the team name, team logo, and Super Bowl
number (usually indicated in [Roman numerals](/wiki/Roman_numeral "Roman
numeral")). The NFL contributes up to $5,000 per ring for up to 150 rings for
the winning team; any additional costs are borne by the team.[1] Most rings
are manufactured by memorabilia company [Jostens](/wiki/Jostens "Jostens"). In
2015, the rings for the New England Patriots reportedly cost $36,500 each,
making them the most expensive rings Jostens has ever produced.[2]

The winning team can typically present rings to whomever they choose,
including usually, but not limited to: players (active roster or injured),
coaches, trainers, executives, personnel, and general staff. Some teams have
given rings to former players and coaches that were on the team at some point
during the season, despite not having been on the winning roster for the Super
Bowl itself.[3][4] Sometimes a team will give rings to fans as part of a
charity raffle.[5] Teams can distribute any number of rings. A recent trend
over the last 15–20 years has been lesser rings awarded to front office staff.
These are commonly called "B" and "C" level rings and are smaller and contain
fewer diamonds or contain faux diamonds. The first instance of this was the
[Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") [Super Bowl
XVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XVII "Super Bowl XVII") ring when many in the front
office received rings that were not solid gold and contained cubic zirconia
stones (which resemble diamonds). When [Tampa Bay](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Buccaneers
"Tampa Bay Buccaneers") won [Super Bowl XXXVII](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVII "Super
Bowl XXXVII"), the players and coaches received rings with a diamond-centered
Lombardi trophy. Some staff received rings with a metal Lombardi trophy and
real diamonds surrounding the trophy and the "C" level ring did not contain
any diamonds.

Many rings feature diamonds in the shape of the [Vince Lombardi
Trophy](/wiki/Vince_Lombardi_Trophy "Vince Lombardi Trophy") or a
[football](/wiki/American_football_ball "American football ball"). Some
feature diamonds or gold in the shape of a team logo. Others illustrate the
number of Super Bowls that franchise has won. Also, the rings are customized
with the player's name and uniform number.

The [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers") [Super
Bowl XLV](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLV "Super Bowl XLV") ring[6] contained more than
100 diamonds. The Packer logo, in the center of the ring, made up 13 diamonds,
one for each title the team has won, dating back to 1929. In a break from
tradition, this is the first Super Bowl ring to be made of
[platinum](/wiki/Platinum "Platinum"), not gold.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots")
[Super Bowl LI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_LI "Super Bowl LI") ring has 283 diamonds, to
commemorate their comeback from being down 28-3 versus the [Atlanta
Falcons](/wiki/Atlanta_Falcons "Atlanta Falcons") late in the 3rd quarter.[7]

## Value and
resale[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_ring&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Value and resale")]

Replicas of the rings for various years are popular collectibles, along with
genuine rings. [Dave Meggett](/wiki/Dave_Meggett "Dave Meggett") is known to
have placed his ring for sale on [eBay](/wiki/EBay "EBay"). Two Super Bowl
rings from the 1970 [Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh
Steelers") sold on eBay for over $69,000 apiece in mid-2008.[8]
[Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") safety [Je'Rod
Cherry](/wiki/Je%27Rod_Cherry "Je'Rod Cherry") raffled his ring from [Super
Bowl XXXVI](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXVI "Super Bowl XXXVI") in November 2008 to
benefit several charities working to help children in Africa and Asia.[9]
Tight end [Shannon Sharpe](/wiki/Shannon_Sharpe "Shannon Sharpe"), meanwhile,
gave his [first](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXII "Super Bowl XXXII") Super Bowl ring to
his brother [Sterling](/wiki/Sterling_Sharpe "Sterling Sharpe"), who had his
career cut short by injury.[10]

In 2011, a Super Bowl ring belonging to Steve Wright, a lineman for the Green
Bay Packers in the 1960s, sold for over $73,000 at auction. Three Super Bowl
rings belonging to former Raiders' [punter](/wiki/Punter_\(football\) "Punter
\(football\)") [Ray Guy](/wiki/Ray_Guy "Ray Guy") brought over $96,000 at
auction. In 2012, [Lawrence Taylor](/wiki/Lawrence_Taylor "Lawrence Taylor")'s
son sold his father's Super Bowl ring from 1990 for more than $250,000.

## Most Super Bowl
rings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_ring&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Most Super Bowl rings")]

  * **Seven** : two people. 
    * [Bill Belichick](/wiki/Bill_Belichick "Bill Belichick"): two as [defensive coordinator](/wiki/Defensive_coordinator "Defensive coordinator") of the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") and five as [head coach](/wiki/Head_coach "Head coach") of [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots")
    * [Neal Dahlen](/wiki/Neal_Dahlen "Neal Dahlen"):[11][12] five with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") (staff and player personnel) and two with [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos") (general manager)
  * **Six** : six people. 
    * [Dan Rooney](/wiki/Dan_Rooney "Dan Rooney") and [Art Rooney II](/wiki/Art_Rooney_II "Art Rooney II"): each as an executive with [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")
    * [Chuck Noll](/wiki/Chuck_Noll "Chuck Noll"): four as head coach and two as a team consultant with [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")
    * [Bill Nunn](/wiki/Bill_Nunn_\(American_football\) "Bill Nunn \(American football\)"): each as a scout with [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")[13][14]
    * ["Mean Joe" Greene](/wiki/Joe_Greene_\(American_football\) "Joe Greene \(American football\)"): four as a [defensive tackle](/wiki/Defensive_tackle "Defensive tackle"), two as a special assistant for player personnel, all with the [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers")[15]
    * [Conditioning coach](/wiki/Athletic_trainer "Athletic trainer") [Mike Woicik](/wiki/Mike_Woicik "Mike Woicik"): three with [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") and three with [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots")
  * **Five** : twenty people. 
    * [Charles Haley](/wiki/Charles_Haley "Charles Haley"), five (two as a linebacker with the [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") and three as a defensive end with the [Dallas Cowboys](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys"))
    * [Tom Brady](/wiki/Tom_Brady "Tom Brady"), five as starting quarterback with [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots"); he has the most rings of any active player (as of the end of the 2017–18 season), he is the only player to win five playing for one team, and he has more than any other quarterback in Super Bowl history.
    * [Robert Kraft](/wiki/Robert_Kraft "Robert Kraft"), five as owner of [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots")
    * [Edward J. DeBartolo, Jr.](/wiki/Edward_J._DeBartolo,_Jr. "Edward J. DeBartolo, Jr."), five as owner of [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * Keith Simon: five as CFO and Executive VP with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * [Bobb McKittrick](/wiki/Bobb_McKittrick "Bobb McKittrick"): five as offensive line coach with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * [Ray Rhodes](/wiki/Ray_Rhodes "Ray Rhodes"): five as an assistant coach with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * [Bill McPherson](/wiki/Bill_McPherson "Bill McPherson"): five as defensive line coach with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")

    * [George Seifert](/wiki/George_Seifert "George Seifert"): three as an assistant coach and two as a head coach all with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * [Dwight Clark](/wiki/Dwight_Clark "Dwight Clark"): two as a player and three as a member of the front office, all with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")

    * [Monsignor Peter Armstrong](/wiki/Peter_Armstrong_\(priest\) "Peter Armstrong \(priest\)"): five as chaplain for [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers")
    * [Markus Paul](/wiki/Markus_Paul "Markus Paul"): three as an assistant strength and conditioning coach with the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots"), and two as an assistant strength and conditioning coach with the [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants")[16]
    * Tim Rooney: Three with [Pittsburgh Steelers](/wiki/Pittsburgh_Steelers "Pittsburgh Steelers") and two with [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") (as Pro Personnel Director/Scout)
    * [Josh McDaniels](/wiki/Josh_McDaniels "Josh McDaniels") has won five with the [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") his first as personnel assistant, second as defensive coaching assistant, third as quarterbacks coach and his fourth and fifth as offensive coordinator.

    * [Tom Flores](/wiki/Tom_Flores "Tom Flores"): First person to have rings as a player ([Kansas City Chiefs](/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs "Kansas City Chiefs")), assistant coach and head coach ([Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders"))
    * [Joe Montana](/wiki/Joe_Montana "Joe Montana"), [Keena Turner](/wiki/Keena_Turner "Keena Turner"), [Jesse Sapolu](/wiki/Jesse_Sapolu "Jesse Sapolu"), [Eric Wright](/wiki/Eric_C._Wright "Eric C. Wright"), [Mike Wilson](/wiki/Mike_Wilson_\(wide_receiver\) "Mike Wilson \(wide receiver\)") and [Ronnie Lott](/wiki/Ronnie_Lott "Ronnie Lott") each won four Super Bowl rings with the 49ers.

    * [Bill Romanowski](/wiki/Bill_Romanowski "Bill Romanowski") won two with [San Francisco](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") and two with [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos")
    * Coach [Charlie Weis](/wiki/Charlie_Weis "Charlie Weis") won one with [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants") and three with [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots")
    * [Matt Millen](/wiki/Matt_Millen "Matt Millen") has four rings while playing for four different cities and three different teams, one with [Oakland Raiders](/wiki/Oakland_Raiders "Oakland Raiders"), one with [Los Angeles Raiders](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Raiders "Los Angeles Raiders"), one with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers"), and one with [Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") (only player to earn a ring with four different cities)

    * [Willie Davis](/wiki/Willie_Davis_\(defensive_end\) "Willie Davis \(defensive end\)")[17] Won all four rings with [Green Bay Packers](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers "Green Bay Packers"): two as a player, one as a member of the [team's board of directors](/wiki/Green_Bay_Packers_Board_of_Directors "Green Bay Packers Board of Directors"), and one as an emeritus director. He is the only person to possess all four of Green Bay's Super Bowl rings. Davis also won rings as a member of the 1961, 1962 and 1965 NFL Championship Green Bay Packer teams, bringing his unofficial championship ring count to seven, as the first three were awarded prior to the creation of the Super Bowl.
    * [Mike Pope](/wiki/Mike_Pope "Mike Pope") won all four of his Super Bowl rings as the long time Tight End coach for [New York Giants](/wiki/New_York_Giants "New York Giants")
    * [Ken Norton, Jr.](/wiki/Ken_Norton,_Jr. "Ken Norton, Jr.") was the first member of 3 Super Bowl-winning teams in a row as a player, and gained a 4th ring as the Linebacker coach for the 2013 [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks")

    * [Dante Scarnecchia](/wiki/Dante_Scarnecchia "Dante Scarnecchia") has won four with [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots") as an offensive line coach, along with being assistant head coach for three of them
    * [Brian Pariani](/wiki/Brian_Pariani "Brian Pariani") has won four rings. One as an offensive assistant coach with [San Francisco 49ers](/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers "San Francisco 49ers") and three as the tight ends coach with the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos")
  * **Three** : many players, coaches and staff

## Players with Super Bowl and Grey Cup
rings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Super_Bowl_ring&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Players with Super Bowl and Grey Cup rings")]

As of 2017, ten players have won championships in both the NFL and Canada’s
equivalent [Canadian Football League](/wiki/Canadian_Football_League "Canadian
Football League") (CFL).

  * [O. J. Brigance](/wiki/O._J._Brigance "O. J. Brigance") (linebacker) won a [Grey Cup](/wiki/Grey_Cup "Grey Cup") ring in 1995 with the CFL’s [Baltimore Stallions](/wiki/Baltimore_Stallions "Baltimore Stallions") and won a Super Bowl ring in 2001 with the [Baltimore Ravens](/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens "Baltimore Ravens"). He is the only player to win both a Grey Cup and a Super Bowl with teams from the same city.
  * [Brandon Browner](/wiki/Brandon_Browner "Brandon Browner") (cornerback) won a ring in [2008](/wiki/96th_Grey_Cup "96th Grey Cup") with the CFL’s [Calgary Stampeders](/wiki/Calgary_Stampeders "Calgary Stampeders") and then won a Super Bowl ring in [2013](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLVII "Super Bowl XLVII") with the [Seattle Seahawks](/wiki/Seattle_Seahawks "Seattle Seahawks"), although he did not play in that game due to a suspension. He went on to play against the Seahawks in the following year's Super Bowl, when he won a second ring with the [2014](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLIX "Super Bowl XLIX") [New England Patriots](/wiki/New_England_Patriots "New England Patriots").
  * [Terry Greer](/wiki/Terry_Greer "Terry Greer") (wide receiver) was the first person to win both championships; he won the Grey Cup as a member of the Toronto Argonauts in [1983](/wiki/71st_Grey_Cup "71st Grey Cup"), and two Super Bowl rings as a member of the San Francisco 49ers in [1988](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXIII "Super Bowl XXIII") and [1989](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXIV "Super Bowl XXIV").
  * [Harald Hasselbach](/wiki/Harald_Hasselbach "Harald Hasselbach") (defensive end) won a ring in 1992 with the CFL’s [Calgary Stampeders](/wiki/Calgary_Stampeders "Calgary Stampeders") and won a Super Bowl ring in 1997 with the [Denver Broncos](/wiki/Denver_Broncos "Denver Broncos").
  * [Bobby Singh](/wiki/Bobby_Singh "Bobby Singh") (guard) is the only player to win a Super Bowl (1999 with the [St. Louis Rams](/wiki/St._Louis_Rams "St. Louis Rams")), and a Grey Cup (2006 with the [BC Lions](/wiki/BC_Lions "BC Lions")), and the [XFL](/wiki/XFL "XFL") Championship (2001 with the Los Angeles Xtreme).
  * [Alvin Walton](/wiki/Alvin_Walton "Alvin Walton") (safety) won two Super Bowl rings with the NFL's [Washington Redskins](/wiki/Washington_Redskins "Washington Redskins") (1987 and 1991 seasons, but he did not participate in the 1991 season Super Bowl victory) and won a Grey Cup ring with the [Baltimore Stallions](/wiki/Baltimore_Stallions "Baltimore Stallions") in 1995.
  * [Barry Wilburn](/wiki/Barry_Wilburn "Barry Wilburn") (cornerback) won a Super Bowl with the Washington Redskins in 1988 and the Grey Cup in 1994 with the BC Lions.
  * [Tyrone Williams](/wiki/Tyrone_Williams_\(wide_receiver\) "Tyrone Williams \(wide receiver\)") (wide receiver) won two Super Bowl rings with [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas_Cowboys "Dallas Cowboys") in 1992 and 1993, although he did not participate in either game. He then won a Grey Cup ring with the [Toronto Argonauts](/wiki/Toronto_Argonauts "Toronto Argonauts") in 1996.
  * [Andre Rison](/wiki/Andre_Rison "Andre Rison") (wide receiver) won a Super Bowl with the Green Bay Packers in [1996](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXI "Super Bowl XXXI"), and a Grey Cup with the [Toronto Argonauts](/wiki/Toronto_Argonauts "Toronto Argonauts") in [2004](/wiki/92nd_Grey_Cup "92nd Grey Cup").
  * [Josh Miller](/wiki/Josh_Miller "Josh Miller") (punter) won a Grey Cup with the Baltimore Stallions in [1995](/wiki/83rd_Grey_Cup "83rd Grey Cup"), and a Super Bowl with the New England Patriots in [2004](/wiki/Super_Bowl_XXXIX "Super Bowl XXXIX").
